title: sun readers debate boris hunt live
story: Both teams appeared much more relaxed this time around compared to last weeks ITV debate.There were jokes aplenty and both candidates ribbed each other and were well received by the upbeat audience.Boris tripped up a bit over immigration and refused to commit to getting the numbers down.But he did rule out an early election # something which will make many Tories extremely happy.They both attacked Donald Trump over his comments about democratic congresswomen, but refused to call him a racist.And they both agreed to having at least one top woman in their Cabinetthey become PM next week.All in all, both Boris and Hunt did well. Most of them answered the question honestly but had a decent dig at each other as they went.All in all, a very entertaining debate filled with fun # and some news too.In just a week’s time we will know which of these two men will be your next Prime Minister.Thanks to everyone for watching, and our fantastic readers for sending in their questions.We’ll have all the reaction from outside Sun Towers to the debate coming up.And on talkRADIO Ross Kempsell will have all the analysis of the last hour’s debate.And now it’s time for our quick-fire round of questions, to finish off the debate.# climate change target of net zero emissions by  keep it  Boris: YesHunt:Yes# continue to freeze fuel duty, like the last  years Boris: Not making any more spending commitments. I would love to. Not a no! I want to. Hunt: I agree with Boris# Is Jeremy Corbyn personally anti-semitic Hunt: Unfortunately, he may be .Boris: I think by condoning anti-Antisemitism in the way he does, he is effectively culpable of that vice.# when was the last time you cried Hunt: That’s a trick question!Boris: When I came out of Parliament to find my bike had been nicked. I had for all of my mayoral career, a beautul bike. It was never nicked during all my time, I used to ride it everywhere. And barely any time into Sadiq’s reign## will you give England cricket World Cup hero Ben Stokes a knighthood Boris: Dukedoms! We will go to the maximum of what the garter kings allow… Yes!Hunt:Of course.# will you promise to give a job to Boris Hunt Boris: Don’t think it would be right before the end of the campaign to announce any jobs.Hunt: Yes.# Who do you want to win Love Island Boris: I have been watching it very dimly. Seems to involve these people with very few clothes on. Amber  Amber is in Love Island! Does he mean Amber Rudd  Wonder what she thinks of that#.Hunt: I don’t know, I don’t watch it.# will you go for a pint with each other when the contest is over Boris: Several!More houses need to be built, both candidates say.This is a huge issue that young voters keep saying again and again is the best thing to get them back on side#Jeremy Hunt just said he would SCRAP the five-week wait # after Amber Rudd made the case to him.#She has persuaded me that we need to end the five week wait before people can claim UC,# he said. #I think its the right reform but had unintended consequences.#And he said he would look sympathetically at unfreezing benefits.But Boris says hes made enough spending plans.#When it comes to the four year freeze, I think Ive made enough spending commitments for the time being##The Suns been campaigning to end the five week wait and cut it down to help struggling families who have been plunged into debt.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mps lords houses in order karren brady
story: Nearly two years on from #MeToo, two new reports paint a bleak picture of sexual harassment in Westminster.The first report, about the House of Lords, found that one in five peers was considered to behave in an inappropriate or high-handed way to staff. One Lord was described as a “notorious bullying pervert” by a Westminster worker.The verdict was that the prevailing culture and behaviour in the House of Lords “has not been conducive to an open and supportive culture to ensure all those working there are treated with dignity and respect”.Worse, the report concluded those staff on the receiving end of bullying and harassment generally did not complain because they thought nothing would change, or feared reprisal.Clearly, the House of Lords has issues. But it’s nowhere near as bad as the House of Commons. The second report, by Gemma White QC into inappropriate conduct in Westminster, concluded MPs’ staff face “unacceptable risk of bullying and harassment”.It found sexual harassment in Parliament is seen by young staff as a “necessary evil”they want to progress. Witnesses describe speaking out against any abuse as “career suicide”.Even though both reports state only a small minority of MPs or Lords behave in unacceptable ways, this has been tolerated for too long and shining a light on it will bring about change.What’s clear to me, both from reading the report and working at the House of Lords, is that this is a generational issue. The House of Lords is full of older people stuck in a time warp.Many of them live in a world where it’s still acceptable for women — often females of a lower status to them — to be patted on the bottom or on the head.The House of Lords can feel a bit like a boys’ boarding school, or Hogwarts. It’s populated predominantly by old white men, many of whom lead a le insulated from the real world.That said, the worst behaviour I witness is usually in the library, where Lords often retire after lunch and which rings with the sound of ear-deafening snoring and, I am sorry to say, farting.The only time I’ve ever seen anyone being actively rude was when one Lord commanded a member of canteen staff to get him a bag of crisps. He was so close he could have reached out and got it himself.I’ve also been on the receiving end of the odd condescending comment, such as when a Lord looked me up and down and said: “You’re dressed rather casually.” I was wearing Stella McCartney trousers at the time, so not exactly jeans.Crucially, though, I wasn’t wearing a dress. So I looked him up and down and said: “Dressing casually is better than dressing badly” — and that was the end of that.It must be horrible to work in an organisation where you feel inferior and can’t speak your mind — and,you do, people either shrug or shut you down. The report about the House of Lords suggested it should be mandatory for all employees to go on a “how to value people” course. Some people might see it as unnecessary — but we send West Ham staff on them and they are good.But that’s not the only change required. There’s neither enough women, nor cultural ersity. The only way that will change is by electing a more erse chamber.In the meantime, I hope this report does not diminish, in people’s minds, the important legislation work the House of Lords does and the role it plays in holding the Commons to account. I hope these reports don’t stop people from remembering what an important institution it is.As Spider-Man said: “With great power comes great responsibility” — and as one who sits in the House of Lords, I know I am not the only one who feels it is a great responsibility.BIG news. MPs have voted to make same-sex marriage legal in Northern Ireland.By a massive margin of  to , the House of Commons backed an amendment demanding the province be brought into line with the rest of the country by October  . . . unless Stormont s and decides otherwise. About time, too.Equally groundbreaking was the House also endorsing a move to liberalise abortion laws by  to  in another crucial vote. Those results came after MPs hijacked a Government Bill in a bid to force through the changes.The DUP has accused them of abusing the impasse at Stormont to impose Westminster’s will. So not everyone is happy with the news.But it’s a big “Hooray!” from me that this kind of right-minded thinking now applies to the whole UK. After all, women have the right to choose what happens to their bodies.And what dference does it make – and whose business is it  – who you love and make love to I FEEL for Donna Bettiss, who is selling her unworn wedding dress after her fiance left her for their wedding planner.Donna, , from Horsham in West Sussex, was devastated when partner James Routledge, , dumped her last year just weeks before their big day. He then started a relationship with work colleague Paige Hannington, , who had helped the couple organise their wedding.Let’s hope Donna gets back the £, the dress is worth. What a cad. Leaving your bride-to-be for the wedding planner is NOT a good look.The only consolation – though Donna might not see it quite yet – is that she is almost certainly better off without him.WHEN I heard a Hull mum had called two of her children Jackdaniel and Tiamarie, all I could think was, “poor kids”.But mum Sarah Mennell insists they aren’t named after booze, as she prefers tea. So I guess the kids got lucky. They could have been called Lionelrichtea and Maryland instead.STRONG contender here for the World’s Gone Mad award.Mum Beth McKenna answered her front door to police who were there after an anonymous tip-off from someone concerned about the welfare of her children.The reason  The kids were in her garden, playing naked in a paddling pool.Beth, from Walkergate, Newcastle upon Tyne, said she “couldn’t believe it” when two unormed police officers turned up at her home on Thursday. And, frankly, who can blame her I AM saddended to hear that the woman who beat a host of men to be named Plasterer Of The Year has been trolled online – and even sent fake porn pictures of her ten-year-old daughter.Steph Leese, , from Liverpool, claims that within  minutes of the announcement, she was bombarded with vile abuse from male plasterers.One person put dog mess through her post box, with a note claiming: “This is what we think of your work.”Men really don’t like it when ladies trespass on what they see as their territory . . . and do a better job.ANYONE  do a double-take looking at photos of Ed Sheeran sporting a really bad mullet Luckily, it turns out it’s just a wig. Love your music, Ed. I’m not sure about your style.I KNOW times are hard but travel agents are now offering package trips that centre around excursions to . . . the world’s biggest Primark. That’s right. You can book a night in a hotel in Birmingham, followed by a Primark shopping excursion.Sure, it’s set over five floors, has three restaurants and it has a hair and beauty salon.But still. Surely we can aim a bit higher than that when it comes to a mini-break Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: suns leadership debate bojo hunts last chance
story: They know the Tories have no chance of winning back their majoritythey can’t secure the support of Sun readers. And both men should realise they still have lots of questions to answer.Boris has promised he will take Britain out of the EU on October , come what may. Good — but how exactly does he propose to deliver in the face of a Parliament stuffed with Remainers  If his answer is a General Election, then how will he persuade fed-up voters to abandon the Brexit Party And what are his tax plans  Will he prioritise cuts for the rich, or start by easing the pressure on the lowest paid Jeremy Hunt’s problem is dferent — he has set out detailed policy plans, but has failed to convince Brexiteers he really is on their side.After an increasingly aggressive campaign against Mr Johnson, how can he hope to bring the party back together in the unlikely event he makes it to No There is so much at stake. As a new report shows, millions of working-class voters are up for grabs at the next election, and it’s vital the Tories don’t lose them to Labour’s hard-left cult.Boris and Jeremy, this is your last chance to make your case to the nation. Don’t waste it.WHAT an unbelievable day of sport!England won the Cricket World Cup for the first time ever, with a finish that could not have been more exciting.And at the same time, two of the greatest tennis players in history thrashed out a stunning five-hour duel with more twists than a series of Game of Thrones.To put the cherry on the cake, Lewis Hamilton triumphed at Silverstone.And there’s further brilliant sport to look forward to in the coming weeks – bring on the Open, the Ashes and more!CARING about the environment is not just for the hair-shirt hippy class.Our new survey of Sun readers shows nearly all are worried about climate change, and willing to adapt their own lestyles in order to save the planet.With small steps such as cutting down on red meat and ditching disposable cleaning products, every one of us can make a dference.The UK is already a world leader in the green movement, but there’s more we can do ­­­– and it DOESN’T require the overthrow of capitalism, whatever the Extinction Rebellion rabble might say.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: omens good real boris brexit
story: The only point of his expected premiership is to deliver Brexit. Pundits give him an agonising  days from next Tuesday to honour that promise.In fact, we will know in an instantBrexit — and Boris — will live or die.The moment will come, perhaps on his first day, as he names the man or woman to prise the Treasury from the cold, dead hands of Chancellor Philip Hammond.If Boris picks Sajid Javid, Matt Hancock or Liz Truss — or anyone  who voted Remain — .million Brits can kiss goodbye to their dream of leaving the European Union.We will end up with a just another bodged version of Theresa May’s BRINO sell-out — Brexit in Name Only. It will be the beginning and the end of King BoJo the First.There will be no second chances. The next Chancellor of the Exchequer must be a proven Brexiteer in word and deedBoris has a chance of surviving his  days.The Treasury is the most powerful and implacable enemy of Brexit. “The new Chancellor needs three key qualities,” says a source close to Boris.“They must have a Brexit pedigree, absolute loyalty to Boris and the intellectual self-confidence to take on Whitehall and the Treasury.”Qualities such as these are scarce in the present Cabinet. The final choice is likely to surprise everyone, especially Remainers.Some names mentioned to me would, to say the least, offer a bracing challenge to pro-EU establishment fanatics who spent the past three years sabotaging the  referendum.Unless the new Chancellor takes them head-on, those forces will crush both Boris and Brexit. Observers have identied the tank traps and sniper nests facing the new PM.He is up against a Remain-dominated Parliament aided by slippery Speaker Bercow, an army of civil service mandarins skilled in the machinery of government and covering fire from BBC propagandists.In the face of such overwhelming odds, a pro-Leave PM is surely doomed to fail. Not so. Despite appearances, Boris has a plan.He will fly immediately to Brussels with a genuine bid to reopen Theresa May’s botched withdrawal agreement.He would seek a clear path out of the EU customs union, single market and European Court jurisdiction, plus a sensible solution to the Northern Ireland border issue.The alternative will be for Britain to leave the EU on October  with No Deal. Unless much has changed, Brussels will say: “Non!” Boris will announce he has no option but to call a snap “No Deal” election.Remainers are appalled at the idea, and for good reason. Poll after poll suggests No Deal Boris would win with an outright majority — at their expense.The public is sick to the back teeth with Theresa May’s dreary defeatism and Brussels’ bullying. Remain voters want this sorted, too.Elections are always risky. But a Tory Party still dithering and paralysed on the biggest issue of the age is the greatest risk of all. Right now, the omens are promising. Labour is committing ritual suicide, shedding voters in droves.Millions of Tory defectors would flock back to a party committed to a final, irreversible Brexit taking us past the October  dead-line and sucking support from Nigel Farage and his Brexit Party.In the intervening weeks, a Boris regime could recruit voters abandoned by both major parties over crime, low pay, high taxes and housing.According to the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, blue- collar voters on less than £, a year, are “up for grabs like never before”.If Boris Johnson has one proven gt, it is for winning against the odds. In fact, despite gloom-mongers, the odds could not be better.To quote Boris, there is an appetite among voters for optimism . . .  stepping off the “hamster wheel of doom”. So brace yourselves for an early general election, folks — and round two of King BoJo.In a PC world gone mad, this is surely the moment to bring in the men women gender non-specic folk in white coats.People now risk losing their livelihoods for invented “hate crimes” on transgender bullying, Islamic extremism or mass immigration.Now Theresa May is transiting into Big Brother by threatening to punish newspapers who publish embarrassing leaks.It is George Orwell’s nightmare novel  brought terryingly to le.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ross clark basu press leaks democracy
story: Police claim to be so overstretched that in some parts of the country they are refusing even to investigate  per cent of reported crimes.Yet at the same time, the politan Police seem quite happy to commit resources to investigate the leaking of diplomatic cables which embarrassed Sir Kim Darroch, who, until his resignation last week, was our man in Washington.Even more bizarrely, the Met has set its Counter Terrorism Command on the operation — yes, the unit that is supposed to spend its time stopping extremists blowing us up. It has threatened journalists, too, that they face prosecutionthey dare to publish the content of the cables.Trying to justy his threats, the Met’s Assistant Commissioner, Neil Basu, said he was sure the leaks had “damaged UK international relations” and on that basis no one publishing the leaks could plead a public interest defence.What a ludicrous over-reaction to what is really no more than a diplomatic spat over the Ferrero Rochers.Sure, it doesn’t exactly help UK US relations when our Ambassador calls the President of the United States “inept” and his administration “uniquely dysal”.But I would say it is mildly less damaging than some of the things that the Leader of Opposition, the Mayor of London and Scotland’s First Minister have said about Donald Trump. I can’t see Mr Basu dangling his handcuffs in front of them — and neither should he.Obviously, Sir Kim has reason to feel aggrieved that someone — presumably in the diplomatic service or the Foreign Office, because there is no evidence of computers being hacked — has leaked information he intended to be private. But it is a matter for the Government to investigate, not the police.How ridiculous Basu has said of the leaker: “You are now also responsible for erting busy detectives from under-taking their core mission.”No, Mr Basu — it is only thanks to your decision that officers have been taken off front-line duties to undertake this investigation.You could have told officials what police officers are forever telling the rest of us when we report our houses broken into or our bikes stolen: Sorry, but we’ve got too much  to do.It would be a dferent mattersomeone had leaked material that really did harm national security.The sort of information leaked by Kim Philby and his Soviet-sympathising accomplices in the s put British lives at risk.But leaking and publishing a diplomat’s private thoughts hardly comes into that category. Mr Basu’s attack on the principles of the free Press echoes Operation Elveden, the failed attempt by the Met to criminalise journalists who had obtained information from police officers, in some cases for money.The Met switched more than  police officers from other duties and arrested  people. The police probe cost taxpayers £.million and yet of  journalists charged, only one was convicted at trial — and that was quashed on appeal. Just one journalist, Dan Evans, pleaded guilty to an Elveden offence and was given a suspended sentence.The prosecutions relied on an ancient offence, Misconduct in Public Office, which was only ever supposed to apply to public servants, not journalists.As many lawyers, including the Lord Chief Justice, pointed out, it simply isn’t a criminal offence for someone to receive or to publish most forms of state information — only for a public official to sell it.There is a very good reason for this. Leaks, and the freedom to put their contents into the public domain, are an essential ingredient of our democracy. It is what helps the Press to keep in check corrupt or over-bearing politicians and public officials.Without the freedom to publish leaked information, for example, we would never have known the extent to which MPs and Lords were abusing their expenses regime.That required a newspaper to publish information gleaned from a computer disk which had been stolen — but thankfully in that case the Met decided that the public interest over-rode a possible offence of handling stolen goods.Without the Panama Papers we would never have known the extent to which wealthy iniduals and corporations have gone into keeping their wealth out of the taxman’s grasp. Without the “climategate” leaks we would not have known how some climate scientists were prepared to manipulate past temperature records to support their theories.It took a leak, too, to establish that the Blair government knew it was unlikely that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, but that George W Bush had resolved to overthrow Saddam regardless.Then there was “Plebgate”, when a leaked police log revealed a bust-up between government chief whip Andrew Mitchell and police manning the gates at Downing Street — and led an officer to be jailed when it was revealed he had invented his witness statement.There are, of course, plenty of other countries in the world where journalists would be locked up for publishing information that has leaked from the government, but they are not countries in which most of us would want to live.By over-reacting to what is an embarrassment to the Foreign Office, the Met has taken a leaf out of the book of President Erdogan of Turkey, who has locked up dozens of journalists as he attempts to suppress all opposition to his regime.Neil Basu and other senior Met Police officers should back off and accept that the Press is quite within its rights to publish leaked information that does not threaten national security.We are, after all, one of the world’s oldest ing democracies — not a tinpot state where people get led off in chains for daring to reveal the truth. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brit tourists madeleine mccann posters holiday
story: The official Find Maddie Campaign website, endorsed by her parents Kate and Gerry, says: “It could be the poster that brings Madeleine home.”They are asking supporters: “Are you going on holiday  Please consider taking our luggage tags and posters. You can download and print from home. Thank you for not giving up on Madeleine.To try and keep Madeleines disappearance in the global spotlight as the summer holidays start, there are printed pictures to choose from in  dferent languages.Dferent images of Madeleine are displayed on the poster, including the photos of her as a three-year-old wearing a sunhat and a scarlet dress and the last age progression photo of her with the message: Have you seen this little girl  and Dont give up on me.Madeleine vanished days before her fourth birthday in May  after parents Kate and Gerry left their children in their Praia da Luz holiday apartment in Portugal’s Algarve.Former GP Kate and heart doctor Gerry, both , from Rothley, in Leicestershire, believe their daughter could still be alive. She would now be aged .The Facebook page states: “Fortunately, there are many cases of abducted children being found and ed to their families - even after long periods of time.“This vital piece of information that leads to a happy and longed-for reunion is usually thanks to a caring and vigilant member of the general public, often recognising a face from a poster.”It adds: In fact  in  children are recovered after being recognised from a poster. It is for this reason that we must continue to remind people of Madeleine and the fact that she is still missing.We are extremely grateful to everyone for downloading and displaying a poster – it could be the poster that brings Madeleine home.Last month the Home Office agreed to grant the politan Police another £, to keep their investigation into Madeleines disappearance going until next March.The Scotland Yard investigation, called Operation Grange, has so far cost £.million.It has been one of the longest, most high-profile and costly police investigations and was started by then Prime Minister David Cameron after the Portuguese investigation was criticised by the British authorities as being not fit for purpose.Home Office chiefs revealed cash for the investigation is provided through Special Grant funding which is usually available to police forces when they face signicant or exceptional costs.Not one piece of forensic evidence linked to the little girl has been found since she vanished.And despite trawling through thousands of tip-offs and potential sightings, police have not confirmed that a single one was her.

story: Last night leadership hopeful Jeremy Hunt said the Work and Pensions Secretary has persuaded him that theres a case to cut the wait down to stop Brits going into debt.And he vowedhe becomes prime minister he will cut it down, helping millions of Brits who are still set to go on to the six-in-one benefit.At last nights Sun and talkRADIO debate Mr Hunt, who is the underdog in the race to become the next PM, said: She has persuaded me that we do need to end the five week wait before people can claim Universal Credit.Which I think is the right reform, but it had unintended consequences when people had that wait early on.Mr Hunt has hinted he would do this before and would look at the benefits systemhe gets into No.The Sun has been campaigning to reform and fix Universal Credit - including slashing the five-week wait and letting Brits keep more of what they earn.Weve told how Brits have been plunged into debt by being unable to access enough help quick enough when they switch to the six-in-one benefit.Sources close to Ms Rudd, who is backing Mr Hunt for the leadership, did not deny that she has been privately making the case to cut the wait times down.But the DWP has said repeatedly that no one has to wait five weeks for a payment as advances are available from day one.One source said: Shes pleased both candidates praised the work Amber has done at the department and we continue to work right up until the final day of this Government.She continues to crack on, and is focused on the job.What comes next is a matter for Jeremy or Boris.Both candidates lavished praise on Ms Rudd last night.Mr Hunt, the current Foreign Secretary, said Ms Rudd cared passionately about social justice - title: man crushed hand sewn back together
story: The victim, who hasnt been named, got caught in the huge press used to condense plastic waste into a cube in Samut Prakan, central Thailand.His thumb, little finger, the tip of his index finger and a large chunk of his palm were ripped off - severing the nerves and ligaments.But incredibly, quick-thinking paramedics recovered the damaged limbs and they were taken to the nearby Chulalat  hospital in Bangkok.After  hours of in theatre, skilful surgeons finally pieced the unfortunate man’s hand back together.Speaking about the operation, Dr. Wichit Siritattamrong said at first the patient was still unhappy with the results, asking him, why didnt you attack my index finger .Dr Siritattamrong, an orthopedic hand and reconstructive microvascular surgeon, said: It upset me a little bit when the patient asked me about his index finger.Then I showed him the picture of his hand before the surgery and he realised how lucky he is to be able to use his hand again.After that he was grateful to all the team who had just saved him from being handicapped.Dr Siritattamrong performed the surgery around three years ago but only revealed the details of it on July  while discussing some of his career highlights.He said that the man has been able to use his hand since the accident and has had no complications since.He said: “The doctor should not try to fix the hand in this situation because most of the time it will they end in failure.“However, the most important thing is that there is an agreement between the patient and the doctor and they understand the procedure and the risks.The patient demand his perfect hand back and I promised him that he will be able to grab things again.The surgery took  hours in total, during which time the doctor had to attach the bone, the ligaments, the blood vessel and the nerves.He finally combined all the parts into a hand. However, due to an embolism had to abandon the tip of the index finger as it could have caused the whole procedure to fail.Dr Siritattamrong added: “The man’s employer was understanding and they re-assigned him to new role more suited him more since his hand was not fully ing anymore.Most of all, I am happy that the patient is happy now and living a good le again.

title: scientists discover cause endometriosis first cure
story: Researchers found a type of white blood cell, called macrophages, which has undergone changes could be the prime cause.The team, from Warwick and Edinburgh universities, ran ious tests on mice and say that targeting the altered cells could be a novel treatment.Currently, there is no cure for endometriosis - a lelong condition where tissue similar to the lining of the womb starts to grow in other places, such as the oies and fallopian tubes.Endometriosis, which affects  in  women in the UK, can occur at any age, but its most common in women in their s and s.It can cause persistent inflammation, pain and infertility as well as agonising periods and ovulation.Surgery can remove some of the scar tissue and lesions, while hormonal treatments can offer relief from symptoms - but can carry the risk of side effects after prolonged use.Without a cure for a condition that affects  million worldwide, an alternative treatment is much needed.Previous studies had already shown that macrophages have a central role in the development of endometriosis.Each month, these cells react in the same way to those in the womb - building up and then breaking down and bleeding. Unlike the cells in the womb that leave the body as a period, this blood has no way to escape.That can lead to infertility, fatigue, bowel and bladder problems, as well as really heavy, painful periods.It affects one in ten women in the UK.Symptoms include:The cause of endometriosis is unknown and there is no definite cure.According to Endometriosis UK, it takes over seven years on average for women to finally receive a diagnosis.Its estimated that up to  per cent of infertile women has the condition.Source: Endometriosis UKThe immune cells help the lesions grow and also drive the development of their blood supply.More recent research has also revealed that macrophages help nerves grow in the lesions.The aim of the new study, published in a recent Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology Journal paper, was to determine the mechanistic role of macrophages in producing pain associated with endometriosis.Senior study author Dr Erin Greaves, who holds positions at both universities, explained that conventional treatments that use hormones are not ideal because they target oianand can trigger side effects, such as suppressing fertility.She added: We are trying to find non-hormonal solutions.The team found that disease-modied macrophages stimulate nerve cell growth and activity by releasing the growth hormone insulin-like growth factor- .They also found that levels of IGF- in pelvic cavity tissue from women with endometriosis were higher than in women without the condition and were in line with their pain scores.Further tests revealed that preventing the hormones activity by blocking the cell receptor for IGF-, reverses the pain behaviour observed in mice with endometriosis.Dr Greaves added: If we can learn about the role of macrophages in endometriosis then we can distinguish them from healthy macrophages and target treatment to them.

title: julio iglesias 3000 lovers
story: But I am responsible for the dubious statistic that has haunted him ever since.My memory ain’t what it used to be, but we met in a hotel room somewhere in London where Julio was promoting something or other, and I had been sent tointerview him for The Sun.But there was one major problem. It’s what he would have wanted.JOBLESS Daniel Eyers and his pregnant partner Lucrezia Worrell say they have been evicted from their Kent council house for spending their rent money on takeaways.The couple, who have four children, are now living with Daniel’s mum. Daniel, , says: “I can’t get a job as it would mean my children would miss out on school, as I have to drive them there every day.”Oh let me count the ways.A flexible, part-time job perhaps  How about your partner taking them to school, or asking other parents for a lt  Or perhaps desisting from having a fth childyou can’t afford to keep the other four Meanwhile, let us compare and contrast this “can’t do” attitude with that of this father in Vietnam who drags his son across a raging, muddy river in a plastic bag so he can get to school, before ing to his remote village to work.A couple of years ago, we cowered inside a friend’s French holiday home as hailstones the size of golf balls rained down outside.Oh how we laughed . . . until I remembered our hire car parked outside.It was peppered with more dents than a Swiss cheese and, because we hadn’t taken out the “full insurance”, left us with a bill that cost more than the actual holiday.A BRIEF chat in front of the assembled cameras at Wimbledon was all it took for the Duchesses of Cambridgeand Sussexto dispel the long-standing rumours of a spat.Several weeks ago, it was also reported that the Duchess of Cambridge had fallen out with Rose Hanbury, one of her closest friends in the “Norfolk set”.The story has been dismissed as “unsubstantiated rumours” by sources within the Palace but it flared up again when Rose attended the recent Trump banquet without her husbandand was seated in practically a separate postcode to her old chum. Of course, they could kill those rumours stone dead too by being photographed together while out shopping or having lunch.That it hasn’t happened perhaps speaks volumes.AMAL CLOONEY is a well-regarded human rights lawyer who, together with husband George, uses her  to highlight ious liberal causes.So I was rather perplexed to hear – via a -page leaked document – that in  she reportedly gave legal advice to Wikileaks founder Julian Assange on how to potentially sabotage the British government’s bid to arrest him.Whether you think Assange’s role in leaking , classied US documents was espionage or heroism, it remains that he was also trying to avoid extradition to Sweden where he faced charges of sexual assault.How, pray tell, does that fit in with liberal values JENNIFER Lopez is  later this month and credits her youthfulness to daily “self-affirmations”.“I tell myself ‘I am youthful and timeless’ every day a few times a day,” she says. It sounds like cliched bull****, but it’s not. Age is all in your mind.”Hmmm. Quite frankly, I could chant her mantra on a loop and never look like this.One suspects that regular exercise, healthy eating and an expensive skincare regime have played their part too.A SMALL number of residents currently living in the swanky London area of Hampstead are up in arms at proposed boundary changes that would place their homes in nearby Gospel Oak.“By severing political ties, you’re disenfranchising many residents,” says one.What they actually mean is: The price of our houses will plummet.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit party heckles ursula von der leyen
story: Brexit Party MEPs booed and heckled the new Brussels chief before the vote for opening the door to another Brexit delay.The eurofederalist won the backing of  MEPs - a majority of just nine - meaning she relied on the votes of eurosceptics to form her mandate.In a mass rebellion over her selection  cast their ballots against her and  abstained, raising doubts about the support she will command.Afterwards Mrs von der Leyen said she understood there was a great deal of resentment over how she was chosen but that a majority is a majority.Referring to the secret ballot of MEPs, she added: I dont know who voted for me. I know it was very dficult to achieve a majority.But one dismayed EU source branded the clf-hanger result an amazing sh**show.In a speech to the Strasbourg parliament she laid out a vision for greater centralisation of powers in Brussels over her five-year term.She called for more Europe on free movement, defence and climate change and touted EU-wide regulation on minimum wages plus a new tax on Internet giants.The -year-old, who will leave her post as German defence minister, also boosted Remainers by saying shes ready to delay Brexit yet again.Labour MEP Richard Corbett crowed: There is a good reason and that is that the British public is changing its mind on Brexit. Keep that door open.Making her pitch to the European Parliament, the German politician said: The European Union has worked hard to organise the orderly departure of the United Kingdom.The withdrawal agreement agreed with the Government of the United Kingdom creates certainty where Brexit created uncertainty.I stand ready for further extension of the withdrawal agreement should more time be required for a good reason.Ms von der Leyens final remark was greeted with a furious reaction from the Brexit Partys  MEPs, who are led by Nigel Farage.They almost drowned out her words with loud booing in the Strasbourg chamber of the parliament.Yesterday she wrote to MEPs saying another extension could be granted “ good reasons are provided” - such as holding a general election or second referendum.Ms von der Leyen vowed to build an “ambitious and strategic partnership” with Britain when she takes over the reins in November.But she insisted Theresa May’s withdrawal pact won’t be renegotiated and is the best and only possible deal for an orderly withdrawal.Her remarks will provide a boost to Remainer MPs who need the EUs help in their bid to block the next PM taking us out with No Deal on October .Tory leadership frontrunner Boris Johnson has vowed to take us out of the bloc on that date do or die.The German defence minister, , said she very much regrets Brexit but that she fully respects this decision made by Brits.She wrote: Brexit creates uncertainty for citizens’ rights, for economic and territorial actors, and for the stability and peace on the island of Ireland.“If elected I am ready to pave the way to the ambitious and strategic partnership we want to build with the United Kingdom.Should more time be required, and should there be good reasons provided, I will support a further extension.Mrs von der Leyen has been proposed by Member States to become the next Commission chief but needed a kne-edge MEP vote to secure the job.Eurosceptics, the far left and Greens all pledged to oppose her in a bid to deal a humiliating blow to Angela Merkel and Emmanuel Macron.

title: striking gritty portraits londoners british
story: The collection of gritty photos make up Blighty - photographer Sam Greggs attempt to depict real London le, from chicken shops to tower blocks.Gregg, , has spent the past year wandering around the city trying to dig up the roots of London, by photographing people from the city and their surroundings.From council estates to school gates, the series pays homage to old family-run businesses and the daily graft of the disenfranchised.A number of the photos were shot in the East End, where the remnants of British culture from the early th Century can still be seen.Gregg now plans to take his project further than just the capital, to get to the roots of the country and what modern Britain is truly like.He said: I wanted to pay tribute to pie and mash shops and all those local institutions before they, and the people that made them, are gone forever”Having spent years living abroad away from his birthplace, the -year-old was struck by his detachment to the city which he once knew.With this nostalgic series, the photographer attempted to get to know the vibrant characters and vestiges of bygone eras from his home city.One striking realisation which Gregg realised during the series, is that to truly connect with his country, its necessary to move beyond the borders of London.He said: “The plan is to go around the UK and meet people from all walks of le.“A country’s rich and complex fabric can’t just be whittled down into one city, of course, it can’t. But London is where I’m from, so it’s a start.So many dferent cultures from the West Indies to India have helped to create modern-day Britain, so its impossible to pin down one core essence.With the turmoil of Brexit and the uncertain political climate, it has become even harder to recognise the characteristics of British identity.The photographer admitted: What it actually means to be British  God knows. Thats near impossible to define.All I know is that us Brits are a complicated bunch, butyou peel back a few layers, we’re just like everyone  – just with an added dash of self-deprecation and sarcasm.

title: jo coxs sister urges britain
story: NewsJo Coxs sister urges Britain to come together after politicians clash under MPs plaqueKim Leadbeater, who runs More in Common in memory of the murdered MP, has launched a call to action - urging people to find someone they disagree with and have an important conversationShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsJo Coxs sister has launched a call to action "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe sister of Jo Cox urged Britain to come together after seeing politicians tearing into one another under a plaque for the murdered MP in the House of Commons. Kim Leadbeater who runs More in Common in her sister’s memory, said there was a “real brief moment in time when politicians said all the right things and said that things would change” after the shocking death of Jo in . But she warned that since then things had got “worse and worse” with a more and more ision then ever in the country and more poisonous language. She said: “If you watch parliament TV which I do regularly and I look at Jo’s plaque which is above where she sat and it talks about having ‘more in common’ and I see some of the behaviour in parliament and quite frankly it disgusts me.” But rather than blaming politicians she urged iniduals to step up and start bridging the ides themselves.     Kim said: “We shouldn’t be afraid of robust discussion and debate - that is one of the cornerstones of living in our fantastic country. We have to do that respectfully and we have to be prepared to listen.” She launched what she called a “call to action” telling the event “go out tonight and find someone you disagree with and sit down and have a really important conversation.” “Use kind language, use compassionate language use language of understanding not language of anger and hate because that’s just not helpful.” Kim said: “I’m still a long way from understanding what happened on that day and what’s happened to our family as a result.”    “I think back and I think ‘how can we live in a country where a woman like Jo who had all the goodness in her, is murdered ’ and it’s made me do some really deep soul searching into the kind of country that we have and the kind of country we want to live in.” She works to bring people together through the Jo Cox foundation, Great Get Together and More in Common Batley and Spen. She was speaking at a Britain Talks event hosted by the Mirror’s parent company, Reach” in Parliament alongside Labour MPs Lisa Nandy and Stephen Kinnock, Tory MP John Hayes, Mirror editor Alison Phillips and Sunday Express political editor David Maddox. The event was co-hosted with theAll PartyParliamentary Group on Bringing the Country Together Post-Brexit, and with My Le My Say, a youth democracy organisation. Retired nurse Ada Pratt from Rochdale, who has taken part in one of the Britain Talks conversations with Remainer Jon, said: “It’s very easy to blame everybody  blame the politicians, blame next door, blame everybody  but everybody needs to get off their backside and do something and it’s only by everyone pulling together old, young, black, white whatever that anything will ever be done.” Lisa Nandy said: “Ive been the MP for Wigan for  years and in that ten years I’ve basically spent half my time in Westminster and half my time in London and when I step off the train at each end it feels like I’m stepping into dferent worlds. “ Brexit wasn’t the cause of it, it’s been coming for a really long time but my God did Brexit blow apart that increasing ision, that polarisation in this country and I’ve seen a hardening of those attitudes over the last few years largely I think because of the lack of political leadership from anywhere across the political spectrum. “But I also feel that we’ve become part of the problem. That sort language like “traitors” and “betrayal” that I used to only hear at far right rallies.

title: kevin pietersen there nothing fair
story: NewsopinionKevin Pietersens open letter to Michael Gove: Its not a sport to shoot a lion for funThe former English cricketer has written a letter to Michael Gove calling for a ban on trophy huntingShareCommentsByKevin Pietersen:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsopinionKevin Pietersensays its time we ALL hit trophy hunting for six "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDear Michael Gove, In your exclusive article for the Daily Mirror yesterday, you say you find trophy hunting troubling and are planning to call for evidence about its impacts. When we met a few weeks ago, I asked you to ban imports of hunting trophies. You declined.You claimed trophy hunting could be good for conservation. This is the absurd argument peddled by the trophy hunting industry.They will doubtless now lobby you furiously following your article.Don’t listen to their lies. Trophy hunters are not conservationists.They are people who kill animals for fun. They then make up excuses to try and justy their so-called ‘sport’. If trophy hunting was good for conservation, why have lion populations fallen from , in the s to just , today  Why have elephant numbers fallen from over  million in the s to just , today  Why are rhinos, cheetahs, leopards, hippos and giraffes ALL in serious trouble     Trophy hunters kill huge numbers of endangered animals every year, and – incredibly - this government lets them. You have to get an import permit from the government before going off to Africa to shoot one of them. Britain lets its trophy hunters shoot cheetahs. Even the Trump administration doesn’t allow that. We’re one of the worst countries in the world for hunting elephants. We’re also one of the worst when it comes to ‘canned lion hunting’. This is the disgusting practice of breeding lions in factory farms so that cowards can shoot them in enclosures. British values are all about fairness. There is NOTHING fair about shooting a tame lion in a cage. But don’t just ban canned lion trophies. We need to ban ALL wildle trophies. British hunters are shooting hippos, leopards, zebras, bears, baboons, and even monkeys. And the number of animals shot is climbing. What sort of legacy are we leaving our children     Britain is a signatory to CITES, the international law that prohibits trade in endangered wildle. But CITES says its rules don’t apply to trophy hunting. Why  Because apparently trophy hunting is not a ‘commercial’ industry. How is an industry worth  million not commercial  Trophy hunters can pay up to £, for their sick expeditions! You have rightly condemned poaching. We need to condemn trophy hunting too.When you poach a rhino, you kill it and take its body parts. When you trophy hunt a rhino, you do the same.The poacher sells the horn to make money. The trophy hunter sticks the rhino head over his fireplace.   It doesn’t matter what we label the killer. The fact is the rhino is dead. Michael, you worked hard to bring in the Ivory Bill. You introduced tougher sentences for animal cruelty. You have a chance right now to leave a lasting legacy.

title: stephen kinnock were now tribal
story: NewsopinionStephen Kinnock: Were now a tribal society after Brexit hardened idesLabour MP for Aberavon on how a fringe issue has become the principal social ision of our timesShareCommentsByStephen Kinnock:,  JUL Newsopinion per cent of people identy as a Remainer or Leaver -  per cent more than voted in the referendum "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritain is a great country, but we are more ided than we have been at any time since the Second World War. Young versus old, city versus town and graduate versus non-graduate - these are the fault lines upon which our country precariously stands. The June  referendum did not create these isions - but Brexit has hardened the ides to the point where we are now a tribal society, with families communities, towns and cities riven, defined and stamped with one of two labels: ‘Remain’ or ‘Leave’. Remember the days when hardly anyone ever talked about Europe, when politics was about jobs, the NHS, social care, housing, transport and schools  Well, those days are gone, for now at least. A recent survey found that half the population identies with a religion and just under two-thirds feels attachment to a political party, yet % identy as a Remainer or Leaver - that’s % more than voted in the referendum.    The story of the last three years is the story of how a fringe issue has become the principal social ision of our times. Listening has been swept away by shouting, persuasion has been replaced by protest and co-operation, compromise and consensus have given way to conflict. We cannot go on like this. We’re in serious danger of tipping over into a culture war, and so we have to find a way of bringing some cohesion and common sense back into our politics. And this is why I am truly proud to be the founder and chair of the All Party Parliamentary Group on Re-uniting Britain Post-Brexit. Working closely with the Mete Coban and his outstanding organisation My Le My Say, our APPG focuses on building bridges and getting people out of their echo chambers. We run a series of award-winning ‘Democracy Cafes’ which offer young people the chance to move out of their echo chambers.

The couple parted with their money in exchange for a deluxe family suite at a complex which was being built as they booked.    “It looked amazing and the TUI store staff spoke so highly of the hotel, Joanne said. Joanne said she became concerned that the hotel would not be finished in time for their arrival after doing research online. TUI customer care discussed her worries and assured her everything would be fine.    She said: “Our fears subsided until a couple of weeks before we were due to arrive, when I was informed that while the hotel would be completed, some of the facilities originally on offer were no longer going to be available such as the spa, hairdressers, the gym and the waterslides.This led me to look on social media. There was a Facebook page full of people complaining how bad it actually was and that the resort wasn’t anywhere near finished.People were cancelling their holidays left, right and centre. We made our way back to the TUI shop to bring this to their attention but they insisted everything was on schedule and it would be fine when we got there.” The couple knew that the children and their grandparents were really looking forward to the trip, so they hoped for the best. The family arrived in Montenegro, only to be met by their worst fears, they say.    Joanne said: “We stepped off the transfer bus to be greeted by the stench of sewage and building noise. The closer we got to the resort reception, the more we saw construction workers walking around with wheelbarrows. TUI reps met us at reception and we were taken to what was supposed to be a deluxe suite. On the way, we came across half complete stairs, loose paving slabs and dust everywhere. story: NewsIKEA oven door explodes sending shards of hot glass all over family kitchenMum Emma Clark has hit out after the less-than-a-year-old Whirlpool oven detonated saying it was lucky the children werent in the roomShareCommentsByBethan SextonKelly-Ann Mills:,  JUL NewsEmma said it was lucky her children were out of the room "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum has hit out at IKEA after her oven door exploded, showering her kitchen floor with shards of hot glass. story: NewsWidow who only ate takeaways sheds TEN stone so her children wont be orphansCheryl Godden, , began overeating to cope with the death of her father and husband who both passed away from cancer in the space of nine monthsShareCommentsByJames Rodger:,  JUL NewsThs Facebook picture which was the trigger for Cheryl to lose weight "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA widow who only ate takeaways every day has dropped nearly half her body weight after fearing her unhealthy eating habits would see her children become orphans. Nearly two years later she has now lost nine stone and seven dress sizes and is a healthy and active mum to son Charlie, seven, and her -year-old daughter Chloe.    Cheryl, from Brentwood, Essex, now a svelte size , said: After Carl was gone my whole world fell apart. The way I was going I was eating myself into an early grave. Losing the weight is an incredible feeling. I just want other people to know there is light at the end of the tunnel.  Itaposs not just your weight that changes but your take on le. Cheryl was devastated when she lost her dad Mick to lung cancer in . It got worse when she was dealt another devastating blow when husband of six years Carl, , was told he had bowel cancer in February . On Boxing Day  the family were told Carlaposs cancer was terminal and he died two weeks later in January . Cheryl, said: I was already in a dark place. It was the first parent I’d lost, and my best friend I was a real daddy’s girl. I couldnapost have got over the grief of losing dad without Carl supporting me. So much so that when Carl died I had no idea how I’d get through without him to help me. When Carl was in hospital having chemo I didnapost want to leave his side.  So I was going to Costa every single day, having three full-fat lattes everyday and a couple of toasted sandwiches. Then Iaposd go home and bung something in the oven. I was just existing at that point. Cheryl saw her weight balloon from  to  and a half stone, while she become a social recluse. I didnapost have any get up and go, she said. Iaposd always order a takeaway for the kids as I didnapost have the energy or motivation to cook. The ease of getting a takeaway just masked the grief.  It would be a pick me up. I just thought my le was rubbish but at least this cake tasted good. I think I was keeping Rowntreeaposs in business. Iaposd happily eat two £ bags of fruit gums or fruit pastilles in one sitting. Iaposd only leave the houseit were the school run. I packed a lot of weight but not a lot of direction. But when I saw the photo of myself, I was mortied at how big I had become! Obviously living off a diet of fast food I knew I wasnapost the healthiest, but something just dropped.  She decided to jet off to Australia in December  after refusing to do Christmas at home without Carl. But during the three week holiday Cheryl found herself constantly out of breath. An unflatttering holiday snap spotted on Facebook prompted her to take drastic action regarding her health. She said: I had a year of sitting around in my tracksuit bottoms. It was on that holiday that realised I wasnapost in the best shape. We were there for three weeks and I missed out on so much. My kids could climb to the top of the hill and take a nice photo but I was stuck at the bottom struggling to breathe. When we were back in the UK I was just scrolling through my Facebook and saw that horrid picture of me.  I was fed up of being a size . As soon as I saw it I was just shocked - thereaposs no other word for it. I was devastated and removed the tag and begged my niece to remove it from Facebook. She joined Slimming World and lost four stone in three months - losing a total of nine stone in  months. Cheryl, who now runs her own slimming group, added: The biggest change was eating freshly prepared food. I feel so much better in myself. I donapost have my knee or back pain anymore.

title: fergie full of praise for don gallagher
story: Lewis Ferguson has hailed the impact of summer signing Jon Gallagher following his competitive debut against RoPS Rovaniemi.The Irishman, who is on loan from MLS champions Atlanta United until January, was a livewire for Aberdeen in the - win over Finns RoPS in the first leg of the Europa League first qualying round.Ferguson played in a deep-lying midfield role last week and the versatile Gallagher operated in front of him in a more advanced central midfield position for much of the game.In the second period the -year-old spent more time on the left wing.But throughout the game Gallagher was a threat for the Dons due to his pace and willingness to take on defenders.He set up the Reds’ second goal with Sam Cosgrove turning in his pin-point cross.Ferguson was impressed with the summer addition and said: “He’s all over the park and he’s so quick and athletic.“Jon slotted straight into position on Thursday and I thought he was excellent.“He had so much energy and was driving forward with the ball and even in the last  minutes he was still driving forward and showed he was a real good ball carrier.“He could have added a goal which would have topped it off – but he was excellent.”Aberdeen were in command against RoPS, leading - at Pittodrie.But Tommi Jantti’s stoppage-time strike took the shine off the performance for Derek McInnes’ side.It also means progression to face either CS Fola Esch of Luxembourg or Georgians Chikhura Sachkhere is not yet assured.However, Ferguson believes a similar display in Thursday’sleg in Lapland to the one the Dons produced in the Granite City should be enough to see them through.The -year-old added: “I thought we controlled the game very well and I thought the standard of football was excellent.“We played really good stuff, especially in the final third.“We created more than enough chances to come in at - or -.“There wasn’t that clinical finishing to put more of the chances away and sadly we’re talking about slack defending at the end that cost us a goal.“I’m pretty confidentwe go over there and play the same type of football with that intensity that we’ll come away with a victory.“They’re a good side and they’re in this competition for a reason.“Their goal was a quality bit of football and that’s what happens in Europe, a split-second can cost you.“ we play with the intensity and energy of Thursday I’m confident we can get through the tie.”

title: money not a factor for ojo

We matched another offer and there was no more money to be had.“It was based on a football decision.“Funso is very articulate, very single minded and knows what he wants.“From that point of view we feel that we are getting a good player at a good age in that position.”Should Aberdeen progress past RoPS on Thursday, Ojo will be available for the Europa League second qualying round.McInnes said: “We first made contact with Funso and his agent just after the last game of the season against Hibs.“We asked to be kept informed.“He had a few things to sort out at Scunthorpe. title: jinski-end-scottish-tour-galashiels
story: BASED on Tyneside, indie folk duo Jinski are song writer Stephen Wegrzynski and musician Dave Kennedy.The partnership forged from acoustic roots and the love of a strong melody is heading to Galashiels next month.Their music touches the borders of folk, country, and pop, keeping alive the song writing tradition whilst remaining resolutely modern.Playing lsquoliversquo with just two voices and two guitars Jinski have been touring the UK, honing their craft, chalking up the miles and making new friends wherever they play.They have built a reputation for delivering music for the head and the heart that is full of passion, meaning and originality.In the last few years Jinski have released two full studio CD albumsand a  vinyl only EP Live Long.Their albums deliver memorable tunes with a cutting lyrical edge, taking the little things that matter and revealing the bigger picture.Guest artists have included the English accordion queen Karen Tweed, New Rope String Band member Pete Challoner , Jez Lowersquos pipes and piano man Andy May and stalwart Neil Harland on double bass.All their albums have been produced and recorded by Dave Maughan .Notable live supports in recent years have been to Lindisfarne, The Proclaimers, Joe Jackson, Kathryn Tickell, Eliza Carthy and Mark Radclfe.They have also recently appeared on BBC  The One Show.Now Jinski are set for a -date tour of Scotland which will climax with a show at the MacArts on Friday, August .Tickets, priced at pound, are now on sale from the MacArts box office on  .Doors open at .pm.

story: SEVEN Galashiels schools are celebrating after winning a national construction competition with a mural in Galashiels.The brightly coloured artwork at Eildon Housing Associations Huddersfield Street development site has been crowned as one of the winners of the  Ivor Goodsite Hoarding Competition.As part of the Considerate Constructors Scheme, the competition aims to fuel childrens interest in the construction industry.The collaboration saw pupils from St Peters, St Margarets, Stow, Burgh, Tweedbank, Langlee and Clovenfords primary schools collaborate in the concept, design and painting stages to produce a champion end product.Pupils also chose the theme of the artwork, and decided to showcase the reasons why they love living in the Scottish Borders.Alison Lowrie, Hart Builders and Eildon Community Benefits Officer presented the schools with their award.She said: "I am so pleased for all the children that took part. story: TO celebrate the tenth anniversary of the opening of the Borders Textile Towerhouse in Hawick, local charity Live Borders is hosting a lsquoStyled in the Bordersrsquo exhibition.Until October the exhibition will showcase examples of the highest quality textile design and fashion from the region.The Towerhouse was established with the aim of giving visitors a new, exciting experience of not only the heritage but also the present and future of the arearsquos textile producers.Over the past decade, Borders Textile Towerhouse has exhibited work from fashion designers, style-creators, single-person businesses, factory producers, artists, and craftspeople.All are linked by the common thread of making high quality, well-designed products, using wool, cashmere and other materials, including leather.The new ongoing exhibition showcases a selection of eight Borders makers and manufacturers - Aero Leather, Eribeacute Knitwear, Frances Teckkam, Hawico Scotland, Jaggy Nettle, Johnstons of Elgin, Teviotdale Arans, and William Lockie.Together they give visitors the opportunity to see examples of the best quality fashion and design coming out of the Borders in .Zilla Oddy, museum and gallery assistant for Live Borders, told us: ldquoBuilding on the rich textile heritage of the area, we are delighted to celebrate the th anniversary of the opening of Borders Textile Towerhouse by showcasing some of the highest quality design and fashion coming out of the Borders today."As a charity, Live Borders is proud to celebrate Borders heritage and its impact on local communities."The Styled in the Borders exhibition runs until October  at the Borders Textile Towerhouse in Hawick.Opening times are from am to .pm, Monday to Saturday, and noon to pm on Sundays.Admission is free.

did over the same period, receiving pound, and pound, respectively.Behind those clubs in the hand out list were Peebles , Duns , JedforestSelkirkand Kelso .Right at the bottom is St Boswells RFC, which received just pound in the last nine years.However, the majority of funding provided to Melrose RFC comes from the economic development fund, which supports the annual Melrose Sevens tournament.A Scottish Borders Council spokesperson said: ldquoThe majority of the pound, funding is economic development support for Melrose Sevens , which when you remove from the total puts Melrose below Gala and Hawick.ldquoThere has also been signicant support for other clubs such as Jedburgh through the common good funds.The council spokesperson also pointed towards a statement given by Mid Berwickshire councillor Mark Rowley, who acts as the councilrsquos member for economic development, in May.He told a meeting of Scottish Borders Council, on May : ldquoThe council would be absolutely delighted to support events anywhere in the Scottish Borders, which have the potential to generate the positive economic impact of Melrose Sevens or the Borders Book Festival, however it is simply the case that such events do not currently exist on the same scale.ldquoScottish Borders Council has provided pound, of funding to the Borders Book Festival over the past ten years from its economic development events budget.ldquoFrom data available for eight of those years the economic impact of the festival has been over pound.million.ldquoThere is a directly quantiableon the investment being made by the council and many others. During that time the Borders Book Festival has also become one of the top three literary festivals in the UK, attracts a raft of household names, and has generated signicant and ied media coverage for the Borders.ldquoDuring that same period Melrose Sevens has received pound, of event development support. From the figures available it has generated an average annual economic impact to the Scottish Borders of over pound.m.,params: .pushldquoThe councilrsquos events strategy and action plan is absolutely transparent in the way in which council funding is used to support the development of certain events over others and attract national and international events to the area, in the same way that funding for local festivals is equally explicit in the way that this is distributed to benefit communities across the Scottish Borders.ldquoI would invite anyone with an event or an idea for an event which has the potential to deliver economic benefits to the Scottish Borders to come forward and discuss their plans with myself and officers so we may explore potential funding opportunities.Scottish Borders Council has also funded three articial surfaces over the last few years, including a new surface currently being installed at the Greenyards.The council has chipped in pound, for the new pitch at Melrose, and has contributed poundm and pound, for the articial pitches at Volunteer Park, Hawick, and Netherdale Arena, Galashiels, respectively.A Scottish Borders Council spokesperson said: ldquoThe council has contributed a similar investment to other G community pitches in the Scottish Borders.ldquoThese include the Volunteer Park G community pitch, the home of Hawick Linden and Hawick Wanderers rugby clubs, and Netherdale G Arena in Galashiels, which heavily involved local rugby clubs in the original concept and continues to see ious age groups regularly use the facility.

title: double-celebration-former-braw-lads-39-president-andrew
story: A FORMER President of the Braw Lads Gathering had double reason for celebration on Friday.Andrew Johnston wasnt just blowing out the candles on his th birthday cake, but the father of two was also toasting  years of marriage to Audrey Aitken.The Golden anniversary couple met and grew closer in their hometown of Peebles.And on July ,  they said I do in the towns Parish Church.The happy couple moved to Galashiels in the years after their wedding, raising two sons, Douglas and Colin.Andrew worked as a telephonist at both the Peel and Borders General hospitals, while Audrey spent most of her working le as a carer and home help.On Friday evening at Quins in Galashiels they were joined by friends and family, including grandchildren Matthew, Lucy, Emma and Chloe for a double celebration.

title: historic-borders-tomb-brought-back-life
story: THE RESTORATION of one of the Scottish Bordersrsquo most signicant hilltop monuments has been completed following a pound, funding injection and the efforts of a group of  local volunteers.The Monteath Douglas Mausoleum, near Ancrum, a gem of Victorian architecture, has been restored thanks to the tireless effort of the Friends of Monteath Mausoleum.The Mausoleum is the tomb of General Sir Thomas Monteath Douglas , whose daughter was married to Sir William Monteath Scott of Ancrum.General Monteath Douglas had spent most of his le serving with the th Bengal Infantry in India and chose the solitary and commanding position at the top of Gersit Law on his son-in-lawrsquos lands to build his tomb.The tomb was built by local craftsmen in , however it fell into disrepair after being abandoned in  following the death of the last family member.More than half a century of neglect had taken its toll on the Grade B listed building, which had been on the Buildings at Risk Scotland register, with wind and rain causing signicant internal and structural damage.However, renovation work began last June, thanks to generous funding from several charitable bodies, and features such as the  distinctive rooftop glass stars were painstakingly restored.The Fallago Environment Fund, which shares the benefits of the Fallago Wind Farm Development right across the Borders, provided pound, whilst the FCC Communities Foundation, a charitable foundation run by waste management company FCC Environment, donated pound,.A further pound, was provided through a Berwickshire Community Councilsrsquo ForumEnvironmental grant.After the structural work had been completed, more than  volunteer hours were required before the Mausoleum was finally ed to its former glory, complete with new safety measures and improved accessibility.Speaking on behalf of The Friends of the Monteath Mausoleum, David Freeman said ldquoThe Friends are thrilled with the successful completion of this project and would like to thank Fallago, FCC Communities Foundation and BCCF Environmental for their generous funding package.ldquoWe look forward to sharing the joy of this spectacular building for years to come.Gareth Baird, Chairman, Fallago Environment Fund, said ldquoThe Fallago Environment Fund aims to enhance the cultural, natural and built heritage of the Scottish Borders and our support of this very special project fulfils all of those objectives.ldquoThe Monteath Douglas Mausoleum is a beautul piece of historic architecture in a stunning location with fabulous views over the countryside and wersquore delighted that we have been able to able to support the restoration and preservation of such a fascinating Borders landmark for local people and visitors to enjoy.FCC Communities Foundation Grant Manager, Sophie Cade said: ldquoWe are delighted to have been part of this unique project.,params: .pushldquoHuge congratulations to the Friends group for achieving a remarkable restoration and breathing le back into this magnicent building.A BCCF Environmental spokesperson said: ldquoBCCF Environmental is pleased to have been able to provide financial support to the endeavours of the Friends and hopes the restored monument will prove to be a well-visited attraction.Walkers, cyclists and horse riders will have access to the Mausoleum throughout the year.Vehicle access will be enabled during six Open Weekends each year, with a guide available to assist less-abled visitors and families to enjoy the surroundings.Visitors wishing to see the angel sculptures and star chamber inside the crypt can obtain a key from the Lothian Estates office in Bonjedward for a small fee.Friends of Monteath Mausoleum are currently in discussions with other stakeholders to improve footpath links to the mausoleum from other tourist attractions in the area.
